DataElement.preferredName: Minimal Residual Disease Next Generation Flow Diagnostic Sensitivity Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the minimal residual disease next generation flow diagnostic sensitivity.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Minimal Residual Disease Next Generation Flow Diagnostic Sensitivity
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Evidence for remaining tumor following primary treatment that is only apparent using highly sensitive techniques._A highly-sensitive variant of flow cytometry used to monitor minimal residual disease (MRD). It makes use of an optimized combination of fluorochromes and antibody reagents for increased specificity at very low MRD levels._The probability that a test will produce a true postive result when used on effected subjects as compared to a reference or "gold standard". The sensitivity of a test can be determined by calculating: number of true positive results divided by the sum of true positive results plus number of false negative results.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Minimal Residual Disease Next Generation Flow
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Evidence for remaining tumor following primary treatment that is only apparent using highly sensitive techniques.:A highly-sensitive variant of flow cytometry used to monitor minimal residual disease (MRD). It makes use of an optimized combination of fluorochromes and antibody reagents for increased specificity at very low MRD levels.

Concepts.definition: Evidence for remaining tumor following primary treatment that is only apparent using highly sensitive techniques.

A highly-sensitive variant of flow cytometry used to monitor minimal residual disease (MRD). It makes use of an optimized combination of fluorochromes and antibody reagents for increased specificity at very low MRD levels.

Property.preferredDefinition: The probability that a test will produce a true postive result when used on effected subjects as compared to a reference or "gold standard". The sensitivity of a test can be determined by calculating: number of true positive results divided by the sum of true positive results plus number of false negative results.

Concepts.definition: The probability that a test will produce a true postive result when used on effected subjects as compared to a reference or "gold standard". The sensitivity of a test can be determined by calculating: number of true positive results divided by the sum of true positive results plus number of false negative results.
